randoop
Interface AssertionTemplate

All Superinterfaces:
Serializable
All Known Implementing Classes:
CheckRepContract, EqualsHashcode, EqualsNotSymmetric, EqualsNotTransitive, EqualsSymmetric, EqualsToItself, EqualsToNull, HashCodeReturnsNormally, Invariant, NotEqNull, ObserverEqValue, PrimEqValue, ToStringReturnsNormally
public interface AssertionTemplate
extends Serializable

Expressions are used in Randoop to record observations about the execution of a statement sequence. See randoop.Observation. A randoop Expression is much like a regular Java expression: it denotes some computation that produces a value. Typically, the expression is over a collection of values. For example, the expression "o1.equals(o2)" is an expression over the values o1 and o2 and produces a boolean value. An implementing class should ensure that:

  • A call to evaluate() returns null, a primitive value, or a String.

Method Summary
 boolean evaluate(Object... objects)
          Evaluates the expression on the given values.
 int getArity()
          The number of values that this expression is over.
 String toCodeString()
          A string that can be used as Java source code and will result in the expression being evaluated.
 String toCommentString()
          A human-readable string representing this expression.
 

Method Detail

getArity

int getArity()
The number of values that this expression is over.

evaluate

boolean evaluate(Object... objects)
                 throws Throwable
Evaluates the expression on the given values.

Throws:
Throwable

toCommentString

String toCommentString()
A human-readable string representing this expression. The string must span a single line. The comment should be formatted as follows: the N-th object that participates in the expression should be referred to as "xN" (for N one of 0, ... , 9). For example, if the expression or arity 2 represents a call of the equals method between two objects, the comment should be something like "x0.equals(x1)". When printing out the comments in code, the xN's are replaced with actual variable names appearing in the sequence.

toCodeString

String toCodeString()
A string that can be used as Java source code and will result in the expression being evaluated. The returned string should not be null. It should be formatted like method toCommentString(), with "xN" standing for the N-th variable.
